paper_info.title: A Network-Flow-Based RDL Routing Algorithm for Flip-Chip Design
paper_info.publication: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems

selected_references.title: NetworkX - Network Analysis in Python
selected_references.citation_context: Implements Cherkassky's maximum flow algorithm (Reference [5]) - the core algorithm for global routing
selected_references.implementation_value: Essential for implementing the core MCMF-based global routing algorithm. Provides ready-to-use minimum cost maximum flow solver.
selected_references.original_reference: [5] B. V. Cherkassky, 'Efficient algorithms for the maximum flow problem,' Math. Methods Solut. Econ. Probl., vol. 7, pp. 117–126, 1977.

selected_references.title: Google OR-Tools - Operations Research Tools
selected_references.citation_context: Production-grade MCMF solver directly relevant to Reference [5] and the paper's core methodology
selected_references.implementation_value: Production-quality implementation of network flow algorithms including MCMF for the wire-bonding pad to bump pad assignment.
selected_references.original_reference: Related to [5] - implements efficient maximum flow algorithms

selected_references.title: OpenROAD - RTL-to-GDS Flow
selected_references.citation_context: Modern open-source EDA tool implementing VLSI routing algorithms related to References [8], [10], and overall methodology
selected_references.implementation_value: Comprehensive VLSI routing implementation including global and detailed routing stages similar to the paper's two-phase approach.
selected_references.original_reference: Related to [8] K.-F. Liao et al., 'Single-layer global routing' and [10] C.-C. Tsai et al., 'NEWS'

selected_references.title: CUGR - VLSI Global Routing Tool
selected_references.citation_context: Modern implementation of global routing algorithms related to References [8] and [12]
selected_references.implementation_value: Implements global routing with network-based formulation, relevant to understanding modern routing problem formulations.
selected_references.original_reference: Related to [8] and [12] D. Wang et al., 'A performance-driven I/O pin routing algorithm'

selected_references.title: Boost Graph Library
selected_references.citation_context: C++ graph library implementing algorithms referenced in [5] and [7]
selected_references.implementation_value: Provides fundamental C++ implementations for graph algorithms including maximum flow for implementing the MCMF-based global routing.
selected_references.original_reference: Related to [5] Cherkassky's max flow and [7] C.-P. Hsu's river routing algorithm

original_paper_references.citation: W. K. Luk, P. Sipala, M. Tamminen, D. Tang, L. Woo, and G. Zobrist, 'A hierarchical global wiring algorithm for custom chip design,' in Proc. 24th ACM/IEEE Design Automation Conf., 1987, pp. 481-489.
M. Katsumata and K. Tanaka, 'Generating routable pin configurations for high-speed LSI packages,' in Proc. Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conf., 1995, pp. 451-456.
S. Tsukiyama, I. Shirakawa, and H. Yamazaki, 'An algorithm for single-row routing with prescribed street directions,' IEEE Trans. Circuits Syst., vol. CAS-32, pp. 167-174, 1983.
C. Sechen, 'VLSI Placement and Global Routing Using Simulated Annealing,' Kluwer Academic Publishers, 1988.
original_paper_references.notes: 1988 book - simulated annealing concepts now in many repos

original_paper_references.citation: B. V. Cherkassky, 'Efficient algorithms for the maximum flow problem,' Math. Methods Solut. Econ. Probl., vol. 7, pp. 117–126, 1977.
original_paper_references.notes: 1977 paper - CORE ALGORITHM - implemented in NetworkX, OR-Tools, Boost

original_paper_references.citation: J. B. Orlin, 'A faster strongly polynomial minimum cost flow algorithm,' in Proc. 20th ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing, 1988, pp. 377-387.
original_paper_references.notes: 1988 paper - algorithm implemented in various libraries

original_paper_references.citation: C.-P. Hsu, 'Minimum-via topological routing,' IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design, vol. CAD-2, pp. 235-246, 1983.
K.-F. Liao and M. Sarrafzadeh, 'Single-layer global routing,' IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design, vol. 13, pp. 38-47, 1994.
original_paper_references.notes: 1994 paper - concepts in OpenROAD and CUGR

original_paper_references.citation: H. Kong, T. Yan, and D. F. Wong, 'Automatic routing for flip-chip power delivery network,' in Proc. ACM/IEEE Int. Workshop on System-Level Interconnect Prediction, 2006, pp. 97-104.

C.-C. Tsai, S.-J. Chen, C.-M. Wang, S.-Y. Kuo, and Y.-W. Chang, 'NEWS: A net-even-wiring system for the routing of clock and signal wires,' in Proc. Int. Conf. Computer-Aided Design, 2000, pp. 120-124.
E. Shragowitz, J. Lee, and S. Kang, 'SURF: An effective algorithm for hierarchical floorplan optimization,' IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design, vol. 8, pp. 1012-1025, 1989.
D. Wang, C.-C. Tsai, and Y.-W. Chang, 'A performance-driven I/O pin routing algorithm for flip-chip design,' in Proc. Design Automation Conf., 2006, pp. 808-813.

L. Luo, T. Yan, Q. Ma, M. D. F. Wong, and T. Shibuya, 'B*-tree: A robust and efficient representation for non-slicing floorplanning,' in Proc. Asia South Pacific Design Automation Conf., 2000, pp. 135-140.
Y.-S. Chen, Y.-L. Wu, Y.-W. Chang, and K.-J. Lee, 'X-Architecture placement based on effective wire models,' in Proc. Int. Conf. Computer-Aided Design, 2004, pp. 830-835.
H.-T. Lee, M.-F. Chiang, Y.-W. Chang, and L.-C. Lu, 'SAFARI: An effective algorithm for flip-chip area I/O placement,' in Proc. Asia South Pacific Design Automation Conf., 2006, pp. 346-351.

analysis_summary.note: The original paper (2007) predates GitHub (2008). All 15 references are from 1977-2006 academic publications. The identified repositories implement the algorithmic concepts described in those references.
